context: In Ireland, private schools (Irish: <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>scoil phríobháideach<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>) are unusual because <a1_1><b6_0>a <a1_2>certain number of <a1_0>teacher's salaries are paid by the State<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. If the school wishes to employ extra teachers they are paid for with school fees, which tend to be <b7_0>relatively low<b7_0/> in Ireland compared to the rest of the world. There is, however, a limited element of state assessment of private schools, because of the requirement that the state ensure that children receive a certain minimum education; Irish private schools must still work towards <b8_0>the Junior Certificate and the Leaving Certificate<b8_0/>, for example. Many private schools in Ireland also double as boarding schools. The average fee is around <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b9_0>€5,000<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> annually<b9_0/> for most schools, but some of these schools also provide boarding and the fees may then rise up to <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>€25,000<a4_1/> per year<a4_2/><a4_0/>. The fee-paying schools are usually run by a religious order, i.e., <a3_1>the <a3_0><a3_2>Society of Jesus<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> or Congregation of Christian Brothers, etc.
